Package dreisoft.tresos.datamodel2.api.attribute

Custom Attributes This package provides classes that allow to implement custom attributes usable in XDM files.

See: Description

  • Class Summary 
    Class Description
    AbstractAttributeTest
    This class is used to implement new tests for an Automatic Attribute of type Expr.
    AttributeTestRegistry
    This class allows to register AttributeTests for the Expr Automatic Attribute.

Package dreisoft.tresos.datamodel2.api.attribute Description

Custom Attributes

This package provides classes that allow to implement custom attributes usable in XDM files.

The tresos DataModel2 allows to define so called AutomaticAttribute that recalcuate their value when the configuration changes. A popular automatic attribute is for example the XPath attribute:

<a:da name="INVALID" type="XPath" expr=". = 3" true="Value must not be 3"/gt;

A special AutomaticAttribute that allows to be extended via Java code is the Expr attribute.

The attribute allows to implement the actual implementation of the test in Java. For this puurpose new tests implementation can be registered with tresos. All tests must implement:

AbstractAttributeTest

Tests (or also called attribute expressions) are registered either via the class:

AttributeTestRegistry

or via the Eclise extension-point dreisoft.tresos.datamodel2.plugin.attributeexpression: 

        <extension id="MyTest_ExtensionId"
                   point="dreisoft.tresos.datamodel2.plugin.attributeexpression">
            <attributeexpression id="MyTest">
                <expression class="dreisoft.tresos.myapp.MyTestExpr"/>
            </attributeexpression>
        </extension>

The above example registers a new test with the name MyTest that is implemented by MyTest which is derrived from AbstractAttributeTest.

The test can then be used in the XDM in the following way: 

        <v:var name="MyVar" type="INTEGER">
            <a:da name="INVALID" type="Expr" test="MyTest(TestArg)"/>
        </v:var>

The above example would call the method MyTestExpr.test() with the parameters:

  • expressionName: MyTest
  • ctxt: A DCtxt that points to the MyVar node in the configuration
  • arguments: Contains the string "TestArg"
